Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Weathered Storms and Following Seas: Fisheries in the Wake of Hurricane Sandy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Drs. Bonnie McCay (Rutgers), Patricia M. Clay and Lisa L. Colburn (both of NOAA Fisheries) will study what factors help people to be "resilient", that is, to recover from disasters more or less easily. Studies of disasters drawn from geography, anthropology, and psychology suggest that resilience differs based on experience, knowledge, tradition, and socio-political context, but also whether a hazard is perceived as caused by the natural environment or by human errors (for example, inadequate city planning or technological breakdown).

This research will further explore how Hurricane Sandy has impacted the daily routines, social life, and work life of coastal communities in the two hardest hit states, New Jersey and New York. Qualitative data will be collected by interviewing a broad cross-section of affected individuals, to see how and how much they have been able to recover from the storm so far and whether they think they can continue where they are or will need to move their homes and/or businesses to new locations. Interviews will clarify these perceptions and the potential influence of changing views of climate change. This study will add data to two other already completed studies funded by NOAA Fisheries.

Policymakers and researchers who are involved in disaster preparedness and relief efforts will benefit from the outcomes of this anthropological study of the New York and New Jersey coastal communities severely damaged by Sandy. The results of this research, together with the efforts of the National Marine Fisheries Service to document the infrastructural effects of the storm, should assist in providing appropriate assistance to fishing ports and communities. In addition, graduate students will gain valuable experience conducting qualitative research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hurricane Sandy: Fishermen’s Narratives of their Struggle to Recovery

Outcome: Hurricane Sandy made landfall in the US on 29 October 2012. New York and New Jersey were the hardest hit states.  Fishing communities were among the hardest hit, because both their homes and their livelihoods are found along and directly off the shore. Through 88 interviews in 9 port communities, various themes emerged.  (1) While most reports discuss damage to coastal infrastructure, we also found concern over changes to the ocean. One fisherman noted that “patterns of fishing have been disrupted… Fish have to get used to what’s new. Then fishermen have to get used to that.”  (2) Fishing communities have been impacted not just by the storm but by government fishing regulations. One fishing vessel owner stated: “between Sandy and the National Marine Fisheries [Service, the government agency responsible for regulating ocean fisheries], they are doing a number on us.” (3) Cultural resiliency has supported recovery for some communities, despite sometimes large physical and economic losses. One fisherman described the post-storm situation as “Like you take everything you own, put it in a trash can, dump it out and pour water and oil all over it.” --. (4) The culture of commercial fishermen and fishing as a way of life have often been noted by anthropologists. In our interviews, mention of fishing as part of a fisherman’s identity is common. Fishermen described at length how they became fishermen, with many coming from fishing families. Fishermen often named their boats after a close family member (wife, niece, aunt). Sometimes they mentioned the age at which they started fishing, the length of time they have spent fishing, or the specific year in which they started fishing. (5) Social bonds with family, friends, and community members were important to recovery.

The role of social bonds was especially evident in a case study in Belford, New Jersey, where the local fishing cooperative – though hard hit -- was a source of strength for the members. A member and fisherman of 40 years stated that “we’re [coop] a resilient bunch.”  He went on to add that because they’ve been there “for generations,” they would recover.   This also underscores the importance of narratives—about the close-knit community, hard-working and resilient people-- which supported the notion of a self-reliant community.  This can be critical to recovery when the availability of outside help is uncertain and slow to come.

Two of the researchers on this study also conducted a large-scale survey in New York and New Jersey on impacts and recovery from Hurricane Sandy. Interestingly, many of the same themes emerged in those results: ecological impacts, fisheries regulations, high levels of economic damage, and the importance of social bonds.

Impact/Benefits: In-person ethnographic interviews delved into impacts from the storm and revealed how and why individual and community responses vary.  The themes identified above help clarify important issues for recovery from this storm and to be aware of for future storm mitigation programs and disaster relief efforts. Moreover, the way fishermen in Belford told stories of how their cooperative had survived hardship before (whether from storms, or development plans that threatened the docks, or stricter fisheries regulations) is a way of thinking about how people confirm and strengthen community social bonds that has not been much studied. This research helps to explore that concept further. Work on cultural resilience, closely linked to community social bonds, will also be enriched by our findings.
